--- title: Adductor Brevis --- :::{layout-ncol="3"} ![Deep muscles of the medial thigh @grayAnatomyHumanBody1918](/The Archive/Images/Gray anatomy 1918 images/Myology/image433 Deep muscles of the medial femoral region.gif) ::: ::: {#tbl-oian .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
Muscle Origin Insertion Innervation Action
Adductor brevis Inferior pubic ramus Linea aspera Obturator n.
L2 - L3		 Hip: Adduction, Flexion, Extension
Pelvis: Frontal stabilization, Sagittal stabilization
``` ::: ::: # Origin {#origin} - Inferior pubic ramus @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Insertion {#insertion} Femur (linea aspera, medial lip in the middle third of the femur) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Innervation {#innervation} [Obturator N.]({{< var ref-obturator-nerve.path >}}) ([L2]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l2 >}}), [L3]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l3 >}})) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Action {#action} - **Hip joint**: adduction and flexion (up to 70°); extension (past 80° of flexion) - **Pelvic Stabilization**: Coronal and Sagittal planes ::: {.callout-note} According to Brad Jones, the adductor brevis is a hip flexor until 50° Hip flexion, at which point it acts as a hip extensor @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ::: # Overview
